question: 1 The narrator of the passage can best be described as
choice_A: A) one of Miss Spivey’s former students.
choice_C: C) an anonymous member of the community.

question: 2 In the passage, Threestep is mainly presented as a
choice_C: C) town that is home to a prominent university.

question: It can reasonably be inferred from the passage that some of the people at the train station regard Miss Spivey’s comment about the Georgia heat with
choice_A: A) sympathy, because they assume that she is experiencing intense heat for the first time.
choice_B: B) disappointment, because they doubt that she will stay in Threestep for very long.
choice_C: C) embarrassment, because they imagine that she is superior to them.
choice_D: D) resentment, because they feel that she is minimizing their discomfort.

question: 4 Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?
choice_C: C) Lines 14-20 (“Irritated . . . excitement”)

question: 5 Miss Spivey most likely uses the phrase “fruitful intermission” (line 26) to indicate that
choice_A: A) she benefited from taking time off from her studies in order to travel.
choice_B: B) her travels with Janet Miller encouraged her to start medical school.
choice_C: C) her early years at boarding school resulted in unanticipated rewards.
choice_D: D) what she thought would be a short break from school lasted several years.

question: 1 The interaction between Miss Spivey and Ralphord serves mainly to
choice_A: A) suggest that Miss Spivey has an exaggerated view of what information should be considered common knowledge.
choice_B: B) establish a friendly dynamic between the charming schoolchildren and their indulgent and doting new instructor.
choice_C: C) introduce Ralphord as a precocious young student and Miss Spivey as a dismissive and disinterested teacher.
choice_D: D) demonstrate that the children want to amuse Miss Spivey with their questions.

question: likely suggesting by describing Miss Spivey as having “wandered” (line 40) in one situation and “marched” (line 49) in another situation?
choice_A: A) Dewey, knowing Miss Spivey wasn’t very confident in her ability to teach, instilled in her a sense of determination.
choice_B: B) Talking with Dewey over coffee made Miss Spivey realize how excited she was to teach in the poorest, most remote corner of America.
choice_C: C) After two years spent studying, Miss Spivey was anxious to start teaching and be in charge of her own classroom.
choice_D: D) Miss Spivey’s initial encounter with Dewey’s ideas was somewhat accidental but ultimately motivated her to decisive action.

question: 8 According to the passage, Miss Spivey ended up in Threestep as a direct result of
choice_A: A) her friendship with Janet Miller.
choice_B: B) attending college in New York City.
choice_C: C) talking with a woman at the WPA.
choice_D: D) Miss Chandler’s retirement from teaching.

question: In the passage, when Miss Spivey announces that she had seen camels, the students’ reaction suggests that they are
choice_C: C) baffled.

question: 10 Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?
choice_C: C) Lines 87-90 (“She means . . . room”)

question: Figures adapted from S. Cairns et al., “Disappearing Traffic? The Story So Far.” ©2002 by UCL.  The main purpose of the passage is to
choice_A: A) provide support for the claim that efforts to reduce traffic actually increase traffic.
choice_B: B) dispute the widely held belief that building and improving mass transit systems is good for the environment.
choice_C: C) discuss the negative environmental consequences of car-focused development and suburban sprawl.
choice_D: D) argue that one way to reduce the negative environmental effects of traffic is to make driving less agreeable.

question: Which choice best supports the idea that the author assumes that, all things being equal, people would rather drive than take mass transit?
choice_C: C) Lines 15-18 (“But they’re . . . productive”)

question: 1 As used in line 9, “backed up” most nearly means
choice_C: C) substituted.

question: 14 In the first paragraph, the author concedes that his recommendations are
choice_C: C) strongly opposed by experts.
choice_D: D) environmentally harmful in the short term.

question: 15 Based on the passage, how would the author most likely characterize many attempts to improve traffic?
choice_A: A) They are doomed to fail because most people like driving too much to change their habits.
choice_B: B) They overestimate how tolerant people are of long commutes.
choice_C: C) They are well intentioned but ultimately lead to environmental harm.
choice_D: D) They will only work if they make driving more economical and productive.

question: 16 Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?
choice_C: C) Lines 31-40 (“If, in . . . worse”)

question: 17 According to the passage, reducing commuting time for drivers can have which of the following effects?
choice_A: A) Drivers become more productive employees than they previously were.
choice_B: B) Mass transit gets extended farther into suburban areas than it previously was.
choice_C: C) Mass transit carries fewer passengers and receives less government funding than it previously did.
choice_D: D) Drivers become more willing to live farther from their places of employment than they previously were.

question: were. 18 As used in line 72, “promotes” most nearly means
choice_C: C) advocates.

question: According to figure 1, how many vehicles traveled on the altered road through the Southampton city center per day before the route was altered?
1 Do the data in figure 1 support or weaken the argument of the author of the passage, and why?
choice_A: A) Support, because the data show that merely moving drivers out of cars can induce traffic.
choice_B: B) Support, because the data show that reducing road capacity can lead to a net reduction in traffic.
choice_C: C) Weaken, because the data show that in some cases road alterations lead to greater traffic on surrounding roads.
choice_D: D) Weaken, because the data show that traffic reductions due to road alterations tend to be brief.

question: Based on figure 2, the engineers surveyed were most skeptical of the idea that in the event of a reallocation of road space, drivers would change
choice_C: C) how often they make a journey.

question: Based on the passage, textbook authors in the early 1990s would most likely have expected which condition to result from the blocking of fast fibers?
choice_A: A) The rate at which other nerve fibers fired would increase.
choice_B: B) The test subject would perceive gentle stimuli as painful.
choice_C: C) The body would compensate by using slow fibers to sense pressure.
choice_D: D) The ability to perceive vibrations would be impaired.

question: 23 Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?
choice_C: C) Lines 12-14 (“blocking . . . shock”)

question: 4-36 (“In contrast . . . 75 m/s”) 24 As used in line 18, “active” most nearly means
choice_C: C) movable.

question: 25 As used in line 24, “capture” most nearly means
choice_C: C) record.

question: 26 Which conclusion is best supported by the findings of Olausson’s 1993 experiment?
choice_A: A) Stimulation at bodily extremities can be sensed as rapidly as stimulation closer to the brain.
choice_B: B) The presence of hairs in human skin lessens the speed with which nerves conduct signals.
choice_C: C) Gentle pressure is sensed not only by fast fibers but also by slow fibers.
choice_D: D) The speed at which a nerve fires is dependent on the strength of pressure applied to the nerve.

question: 27 Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?
choice_C: C) Lines 28-30 (“The delay . . . later”)

question: 28 The sentence in lines 43-45 (“But . . . mystifying”) serves mainly to
choice_A: A) identify factors that Olausson had previously failed to consider.
choice_B: B) propose a solution to a dilemma encountered by Olausson.
choice_C: C) anticipate a potential criticism of Olausson by the reader.
choice_D: D) show a problem from the perspective of Olausson’s team.

question: 1 It can reasonably be inferred that one of the intended goals of the 1999 experiment was to determine the
choice_A: A) precise nature of sensations that CT fibers can convey.
choice_B: B) relationship between body hair and CT fiber function.
choice_C: C) role played by CT fibers in the perception of pain.
choice_D: D) effect of microneurography on CT fiber signaling.

question: 30 The main purpose of the sixth paragraph (lines 64-75) is to
choice_A: A) identify those of G.L.’s neurological conditions that might be relieved by the experiment.
choice_B: B) contextualize the nerve function of G.L. by comparing it with that of other adults.
choice_C: C) detail procedures that G.L. had experienced during previous experiments.
choice_D: D) indicate why G.L.’s medical condition was of value to Olausson’s experiment.

question: 31 According to the passage, G.L. differed from Olausson’s other test subjects in terms of the
choice_A: A) number of cortices activated in the brain during gentle brushing.
choice_B: B) physical dimensions of the somatosensory cortex.
choice_C: C) intensity of nerve signals required to activate the insular cortex.
choice_D: D) effect of MRI scanning on the basic function of brain cortices.

question: 32 According to the passage, humans experience an emotional aspect of touch when
choice_A: A) brain cortices are shielded from nerve signals.
choice_B: B) CT fibers are exposed to a stimulus.
choice_C: C) nerve fibers that sense pain are suppressed.
choice_D: D) conscious aspects of sensation are ignored.

question: 1 In Passage 1, Beveridge asserts that the resources and immensity of the United States constitute a
choice_B: B) replication of conditions in Europe.
choice_C: C) divine gift to the American people.
choice_D: D) source of envy for people in other countries.

question: 34 In the second paragraph of Passage 1 (lines 26-41), the commands given by Beveridge mainly serve to
choice_A: A) remind the audience of its civic responsibilities.
choice_B: B) anticipate the benefits of a proposed policy.
choice_C: C) emphasize the urgency of a national problem.
choice_D: D) refute arguments that opponents have advanced.

question: 35 As used in line 72, “recalled” most nearly means
choice_C: C) rejected.

question: It can reasonably be inferred from Passage 2 that Bryan considers the preference for national sovereignty over foreign rule to be a
choice_A: A) reaction to the excesses of imperial governments in the modern era.
choice_B: B) sign that the belief in human equality is widespread.
choice_C: C) testament to the effects of the foreign policy of the United States.
choice_D: D) manifestation of an innate drive in humans toward self-rule.

question: 37 Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?
choice_C: C) Lines 79-81 (“He never . . . master”)

question: 2-85 (“Those . . . nation”) 38 As used in line 85, “calculate” most nearly means
choice_C: C) assume.

question: In developing their respective arguments, Beveridge (Passage 1) and Bryan (Passage 2) both express admiration for the
choice_A: A) founding and history of the United States.
choice_B: B) vibrancy and diversity of American culture.
choice_C: C) worldwide history of struggles for independence.
choice_D: D) idealism that permeates many aspects of American society.

question: Which choice best describes a central difference between how Beveridge (Passage 1) and Bryan (Passage 2) view the concept of liberty as it is realized in the United States?
choice_A: A) Beveridge presents it as the direct inheritance of European colonization, whereas Bryan presents it as a sharp break from earlier governments in Europe.
choice_B: B) Beveridge considers it so exemplary as to justify conquest of other regions, whereas Bryan warns that its exemplary quality would be undermined by imperial expansion.
choice_C: C) Beveridge argues that it arose organically as the United States matured, whereas Bryan argues that it was present from the country’s beginnings.
choice_D: D) Beveridge regards it as a model that should be shared with other countries, whereas Bryan believes that it is unique to the United States and could not work elsewhere.

question: It can most reasonably be inferred from Passage 2 that Bryan would criticize the vision of American governance of island territories that Beveridge presents in Passage 1 for being
choice_A: A) unrealistic, since most Americans would be unwilling to relocate to distant islands.
choice_B: B) deceptive, since economic domination would be the true goal of the American government.
choice_C: C) impractical, since the islanders would insist upon an equal distribution of resources.
choice_D: D) naive, since the islanders would object to being governed by Americans.

question: 42 Which choice from Passage 2 provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?
choice_C: C) Lines 50-53 (“Our . . . government”)

question: 43 According to the passage, exposure to light allows seeds to
choice_C: C) withstand extreme temperatures.

question: 44 The question in the second paragraph (lines 13-17) primarily serves to
choice_A: A) emphasize the provisional nature of the findings discussed in the passage.
choice_B: B) introduce the specific research topic addressed in the passage.
choice_C: C) suggest the hypothetical impact of the studies analyzed in the passage.
choice_D: D) indicate the level of disagreement about the methods explored in the passage.

question: 45 As used in line 16, “induced” most nearly means
choice_C: C) convinced.

question: Which choice best supports the idea that seeds present in fields plowed at night are exposed to some amount of light?
choice_C: C) Lines 43-47 (“Although . . . seeds”)

question: or corn on the two agricultural strips in Hartmann’s experiment, the percentage of the surface of each strip covered with weeds would likely have been
choice_A: A) lower than the percentage that Hartmann found.
choice_B: B) higher than the percentage that Hartmann had predicted.
choice_C: C) nearly impossible for Hartmann to determine.
choice_D: D) comparable to Hartmann’s original projection.

question: 48 Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?
choice_C: C) Line 62 (“The results . . . dramatic”)

question: 1 As used in line 62, “dramatic” most nearly means
choice_C: C) impressive.

question: According to the table, in which soil sample disturbed in darkness did the fewest number of seedlings emerge?
choice_C: C) Sample C

question: 51 As presented in the table, which sample produced the most seedlings when the soil was disturbed in light?
choice_C: C) Sample I

question: 52 The data presented in the table most directly support which claim from the passage?
choice_C: C) Lines 10-13 (“Plant . . . germinate”)
